and not the fruits of experience, sweet or

19840.text:
bitter as they might be. Of the asceticism
that deadens the senses, as of the vulgar

19847.text:
profligacy that dulls them, it was to know
nothing. But it was to teach man to concentrate

19854.text:
himself upon the moments of a life that is
itself but a moment.

19860.text:
There are few of us who have not sometimes
wakened before dawn, either after one of those

19866.text:
dreamless nights that make us almost enamoured
of death, or one of those nights of horror

19871.text:
and misshapen joy, when through the chambers
of the brain sweep phantoms more terrible

19877.text:
than reality itself, and instinct with that
vivid life that lurks in all grotesques, and

19884.text:
that lends to Gothic art its enduring vitality,
this art being, one might fancy, especially

19891.text:
the art of those whose minds have been troubled
with the malady of reverie. Gradually white

19898.text:
fingers creep through the curtains, and they
appear to tremble. In black fantastic shapes,

19905.text:
dumb shadows crawl into the corners of the
room and crouch there. Outside, there is the

19911.text:
stirring of birds among the leaves, or the
sound of men going forth to their work, or

19916.text:
the sigh and sob of the wind coming down from
the hills and wandering round the silent house,

19923.text:
as though it feared to wake the sleepers and
yet must needs call forth sleep from her purple

19929.text:
cave. Veil after veil of thin dusky gauze
is lifted, and by degrees the forms and colours

19937.text:
of things are restored to them, and we watch
the dawn remaking the world in its antique

19943.text:
pattern. The wan mirrors get back their mimic
life. The flameless tapers stand where we

19950.text:
had left them, and beside them lies the half-cut
book that we had been studying, or the wired

19956.text:
flower that we had worn at the ball, or the
letter that we had been afraid to read, or

19962.text:
that we had read too often. Nothing seems
to us changed. Out of the unreal shadows of

19970.text:
the night comes back the real life that we
had known. We have to resume it where we had

19977.text:
left off, and there steals over us a terrible
sense of the necessity for the continuance

19983.text:
of energy in the same wearisome round of stereotyped
habits, or a wild longing, it may be, that

19991.text:
our eyelids might open some morning upon a
world that had been refashioned anew in the

19997.text:
darkness for our pleasure, a world in which
things would have fresh shapes and colours,

20002.text:
and be changed, or have other secrets, a world
in which the past would have little or no

20009.text:
place, or survive, at any rate, in no conscious
form of obligation or regret, the remembrance

20015.text:
even of joy having its bitterness and the
memories of pleasure their pain.

20021.text:
It was the creation of such worlds as these
that seemed to Dorian Gray to be the true

20027.text:
object, or amongst the true objects, of life;
and in his search for sensations that would

20033.text:
be at once new and delightful, and possess
that element of strangeness that is so essential

20038.text:
to romance, he would often adopt certain modes
of thought that he knew to be really alien

20044.text:
to his nature, abandon himself to their subtle
influences, and then, having, as it were,

20050.text:
caught their colour and satisfied his intellectual
curiosity, leave them with that curious indifference

20057.text:
that is not incompatible with a real ardour
of temperament, and that, indeed, according

20063.text:
to certain modern psychologists, is often
a condition of it.

20067.text:
It was rumoured of him once that he was about
to join the Roman Catholic communion, and

20073.text:
certainly the Roman ritual had always a great
attraction for him. The daily sacrifice, more

20079.text:
awful really than all the sacrifices of the
antique world, stirred him as much by its

20085.text:
superb rejection of the evidence of the senses
as by the primitive simplicity of its elements

20091.text:
and the eternal pathos of the human tragedy
that it sought to symbolize. He loved to kneel

20097.text:
down on the cold marble pavement and watch
the priest, in his stiff flowered dalmatic,

20103.text:
slowly and with white hands moving aside the
veil of the tabernacle, or raising aloft the

20109.text:
jewelled, lantern-shaped monstrance with that
pallid wafer that at times, one would fain

20115.text:
think, is indeed the "panis caelestis," the
bread of angels, or, robed in the garments

20121.text:
of the Passion of Christ, breaking the Host
into the chalice and smiting his breast for

20125.text:
his sins. The fuming censers that the grave
boys, in their lace and scarlet, tossed into

20132.text:
the air like great gilt flowers had their
subtle fascination for him. As he passed out,

20139.text:
he used to look with wonder at the black confessionals
and long to sit in the dim shadow of one of

20145.text:
them and listen to men and women whispering
through the worn grating the true story of

But he never fell into the error of arresting
his intellectual development by any formal

20158.text:
acceptance of creed or system, or of mistaking,
for a house in which to live, an inn that

20165.text:
is but suitable for the sojourn of a night,
or for a few hours of a night in which there

20170.text:
are no stars and the moon is in travail. Mysticism,
with its marvellous power of making common

20177.text:
things strange to us, and the subtle antinomianism
that always seems to accompany it, moved him

20184.text:
for a season; and for a season he inclined
to the materialistic doctrines of the Darwinismus

20191.text:
movement in Germany, and found a curious pleasure
in tracing the thoughts and passions of men

20197.text:
to some pearly cell in the brain, or some
white nerve in the body, delighting in the

20203.text:
conception of the absolute dependence of the
spirit on certain physical conditions, morbid

20209.text:
or healthy, normal or diseased. Yet, as has
been said of him before, no theory of life

20219.text:
seemed to him to be of any importance compared
with life itself. He felt keenly conscious

20225.text:
of how barren all intellectual speculation
is when separated from action and experiment.

20231.text:
He knew that the senses, no less than the
soul, have their spiritual mysteries to reveal.

20240.text:
And so he would now study perfumes and the
secrets of their manufacture, distilling heavily

20246.text:
scented oils and burning odorous gums from
the East. He saw that there was no mood of

20252.text:
the mind that had not its counterpart in the
sensuous life, and set himself to discover

20257.text:
their true relations, wondering what there
was in frankincense that made one mystical,

20263.text:
and in ambergris that stirred one's passions,
and in violets that woke the memory of dead

20269.text:
romances, and in musk that troubled the brain,
and in champak that stained the imagination;

20275.text:
and seeking often to elaborate a real psychology
of perfumes, and to estimate the several influences

20281.text:
of sweet-smelling roots and scented, pollen-laden
flowers; of aromatic balms and of dark and

20288.text:
fragrant woods; of spikenard, that sickens;
of hovenia, that makes men mad; and of aloes,

20296.text:
that are said to be able to expel melancholy
from the soul.

20300.text:
At another time he devoted himself entirely
to music, and in a long latticed room, with

20307.text:
a vermilion-and-gold ceiling and walls of
olive-green lacquer, he used to give curious

20312.text:
concerts in which mad gipsies tore wild music
from little zithers, or grave, yellow-shawled

20319.text:
Tunisians plucked at the strained strings
of monstrous lutes, while grinning Negroes

20325.text:
beat monotonously upon copper drums and, crouching
upon scarlet mats, slim turbaned Indians blew

20333.text:
through long pipes of reed or brass and charmed—or
feigned to charm—great hooded snakes and

20341.text:
horrible horned adders. The harsh intervals
and shrill discords of barbaric music stirred

20348.text:
him at times when Schubert's grace, and Chopin's
beautiful sorrows, and the mighty harmonies

20353.text:
of Beethoven himself, fell unheeded on his
ear. He collected together from all parts

20361.text:
of the world the strangest instruments that
could be found, either in the tombs of dead

20367.text:
nations or among the few savage tribes that
have survived contact with Western civilizations,

20374.text:
and loved to touch and try them. He had the
mysterious juruparis of the Rio Negro Indians,

20382.text:
that women are not allowed to look at and
that even youths may not see till they have

20387.text:
been subjected to fasting and scourging, and
the earthen jars of the Peruvians that have

20393.text:
the shrill cries of birds, and flutes of human
bones such as Alfonso de Ovalle heard in Chile,

20400.text:
and the sonorous green jaspers that are found
near Cuzco and give forth a note of singular

20406.text:
sweetness. He had painted gourds filled with
pebbles that rattled when they were shaken;

20413.text:
the long clarin of the Mexicans, into which
the performer does not blow, but through which

20419.text:
he inhales the air; the harsh ture of the
Amazon tribes, that is sounded by the sentinels

20426.text:
who sit all day long in high trees, and can
be heard, it is said, at a distance of three

20433.text:
leagues; the teponaztli, that has two vibrating
tongues of wood and is beaten with sticks

20439.text:
that are smeared with an elastic gum obtained
from the milky juice of plants; the yotl-bells

20445.text:
of the Aztecs, that are hung in clusters like
grapes; and a huge cylindrical drum, covered

20452.text:
with the skins of great serpents, like the
one that Bernal Diaz saw when he went with

20457.text:
Cortes into the Mexican temple, and of whose
doleful sound he has left us so vivid a description.

20465.text:
The fantastic character of these instruments
fascinated him, and he felt a curious delight

20471.text:
in the thought that art, like Nature, has
her monsters, things of bestial shape and

20478.text:
with hideous voices. Yet, after some time,
he wearied of them, and would sit in his box

20485.text:
at the opera, either alone or with Lord Henry,
listening in rapt pleasure to "Tannhauser"

20492.text:
and seeing in the prelude to that great work
of art a presentation of the tragedy of his

20499.text:
On one occasion he took up the study of jewels,
and appeared at a costume ball as Anne de

20506.text:
Joyeuse, Admiral of France, in a dress covered
with five hundred and sixty pearls. This taste

20514.text:
enthralled him for years, and, indeed, may
be said never to have left him. He would often

20520.text:
spend a whole day settling and resettling
in their cases the various stones that he

20525.text:
had collected, such as the olive-green chrysoberyl
that turns red by lamplight, the cymophane

20531.text:
with its wirelike line of silver, the pistachio-coloured
peridot, rose-pink and wine-yellow topazes,

20539.text:
carbuncles of fiery scarlet with tremulous,
four-rayed stars, flame-red cinnamon-stones,

20546.text:
orange and violet spinels, and amethysts with
their alternate layers of ruby and sapphire.

20553.text:
He loved the red gold of the sunstone, and
the moonstone's pearly whiteness, and the

20560.text:
broken rainbow of the milky opal. He procured
from Amsterdam three emeralds of extraordinary

20567.text:
size and richness of colour, and had a turquoise
de la vieille roche that was the envy of all

20577.text:
He discovered wonderful stories, also, about
jewels. In Alphonso's Clericalis Disciplina

20583.text:
a serpent was mentioned with eyes of real
jacinth, and in the romantic history of Alexander,

20589.text:
the Conqueror of Emathia was said to have
found in the vale of Jordan snakes "with collars

20595.text:
of real emeralds growing on their backs."
There was a gem in the brain of the dragon,

20601.text:
Philostratus told us, and "by the exhibition
of golden letters and a scarlet robe" the

20607.text:
monster could be thrown into a magical sleep
and slain. According to the great alchemist,

20613.text:
Pierre de Boniface, the diamond rendered a
man invisible, and the agate of India made

20619.text:
him eloquent. The cornelian appeased anger,
and the hyacinth provoked sleep, and the amethyst

20626.text:
drove away the fumes of wine. The garnet cast
out demons, and the hydropicus deprived the

20634.text:
moon of her colour. The selenite waxed and
waned with the moon, and the meloceus, that

20641.text:
discovers thieves, could be affected only
by the blood of kids. Leonardus Camillus had

20648.text:
seen a white stone taken from the brain of
a newly killed toad, that was a certain antidote

20653.text:
against poison. The bezoar, that was found
in the heart of the Arabian deer, was a charm

20660.text:
that could cure the plague. In the nests of
Arabian birds was the aspilates, that, according

20667.text:
to Democritus, kept the wearer from any danger
by fire.

20672.text:
The King of Ceilan rode through his city with
a large ruby in his hand, as the ceremony

20677.text:
of his coronation. The gates of the palace
of John the Priest were "made of sardius,

20682.text:
with the horn of the horned snake inwrought,
so that no man might bring poison within."

20689.text:
Over the gable were "two golden apples, in
which were two carbuncles," so that the gold

20695.text:
might shine by day and the carbuncles by night.
In Lodge's strange romance 'A Margarite of

20703.text:
America', it was stated that in the chamber
of the queen one could behold "all the chaste

20709.text:
ladies of the world, inchased out of silver,
looking through fair mirrours of chrysolites,

20714.text:
carbuncles, sapphires, and greene emeraults."
Marco Polo had seen the inhabitants of Zipangu

20722.text:
place rose-coloured pearls in the mouths of
the dead. A sea-monster had been enamoured

20728.text:
of the pearl that the diver brought to King
Perozes, and had slain the thief, and mourned

20734.text:
for seven moons over its loss. When the Huns
lured the king into the great pit, he flung

20741.text:
it away—Procopius tells the story—nor
was it ever found again, though the Emperor

20747.text:
Anastasius offered five hundred-weight of
gold pieces for it. The King of Malabar had

20754.text:
shown to a certain Venetian a rosary of three
hundred and four pearls, one for every god

20763.text:
When the Duke de Valentinois, son of Alexander
VI, visited Louis XII of France, his horse

20769.text:
was loaded with gold leaves, according to
Brantome, and his cap had double rows of rubies

20775.text:
that threw out a great light. Charles of England
had ridden in stirrups hung with four hundred

20782.text:
and twenty-one diamonds. Richard II had a
coat, valued at thirty thousand marks, which

20789.text:
was covered with balas rubies. Hall described
Henry VIII, on his way to the Tower previous

20795.text:
to his coronation, as wearing "a jacket of
raised gold, the placard embroidered with

20800.text:
diamonds and other rich stones, and a great
bauderike about his neck of large balasses."

20807.text:
The favourites of James I wore ear-rings of
emeralds set in gold filigrane. Edward II

20813.text:
gave to Piers Gaveston a suit of red-gold
armour studded with jacinths, a collar of

20820.text:
gold roses set with turquoise-stones, and
a skull-cap parseme with pearls. Henry II

20827.text:
wore jewelled gloves reaching to the elbow,
and had a hawk-glove sewn with twelve rubies

20832.text:
and fifty-two great orients. The ducal hat
of Charles the Rash, the last Duke of Burgundy

20839.text:
of his race, was hung with pear-shaped pearls
and studded with sapphires.

20844.text:
How exquisite life had once been! How gorgeous
in its pomp and decoration! Even to read of

20853.text: the luxury of the dead was wonderful.

20856.text:
Then he turned his attention to embroideries
and to the tapestries that performed the office

20862.text:
of frescoes in the chill rooms of the northern
nations of Europe. As he investigated the

20868.text:
subject—and he always had an extraordinary
faculty of becoming absolutely absorbed for

20873.text:
the moment in whatever he took up—he was
almost saddened by the reflection of the ruin

20878.text:
that time brought on beautiful and wonderful
things. He, at any rate, had escaped that.

20886.text:
Summer followed summer, and the yellow jonquils
bloomed and died many times, and nights of

20892.text:
horror repeated the story of their shame,
but he was unchanged. No winter marred his

20899.text:
face or stained his flowerlike bloom. How
different it was with material things! Where

20907.text:
had they passed to? Where was the great crocus-coloured
robe, on which the gods fought against the

20914.text:
giants, that had been worked by brown girls
for the pleasure of Athena? Where the huge

20919.text:
velarium that Nero had stretched across the
Colosseum at Rome, that Titan sail of purple

20926.text:
on which was represented the starry sky, and
Apollo driving a chariot drawn by white, gilt-reined

20932.text:
steeds? He longed to see the curious table-napkins
wrought for the Priest of the Sun, on which

20940.text:
were displayed all the dainties and viands
that could be wanted for a feast; the mortuary

20946.text:
cloth of King Chilperic, with its three hundred
golden bees; the fantastic robes that excited

20953.text:
the indignation of the Bishop of Pontus and
were figured with "lions, panthers, bears,

20959.text:
dogs, forests, rocks, hunters—all, in fact,
that a painter can copy from nature"; and

20966.text:
the coat that Charles of Orleans once wore,
on the sleeves of which were embroidered the

20971.text:
verses of a song beginning "Madame, je suis
tout joyeux," the musical accompaniment of

20978.text:
the words being wrought in gold thread, and
each note, of square shape in those days,

20984.text:
formed with four pearls. He read of the room
that was prepared at the palace at Rheims

20990.text:
for the use of Queen Joan of Burgundy and
was decorated with "thirteen hundred and twenty-one

20996.text:
parrots, made in broidery, and blazoned with
the king's arms, and five hundred and sixty-one

21002.text:
butterflies, whose wings were similarly ornamented
with the arms of the queen, the whole worked

21009.text:
in gold." Catherine de Medicis had a mourning-bed
made for her of black velvet powdered with

21016.text:
crescents and suns. Its curtains were of damask,
with leafy wreaths and garlands, figured upon

21022.text:
a gold and silver ground, and fringed along
the edges with broideries of pearls, and it

21029.text:
stood in a room hung with rows of the queen's
devices in cut black velvet upon cloth of

21034.text:
silver. Louis XIV had gold embroidered caryatides
fifteen feet high in his apartment. The state

21043.text:
bed of Sobieski, King of Poland, was made
of Smyrna gold brocade embroidered in turquoises

21049.text:
with verses from the Koran. Its supports were
of silver gilt, beautifully chased, and profusely

21056.text:
set with enamelled and jewelled medallions.
It had been taken from the Turkish camp before

21061.text:
Vienna, and the standard of Mohammed had stood
beneath the tremulous gilt of its canopy.

And so, for a whole year, he sought to accumulate
the most exquisite specimens that he could

21074.text:
find of textile and embroidered work, getting
the dainty Delhi muslins, finely wrought with

21081.text:
gold-thread palmates and stitched over with
iridescent beetles' wings; the Dacca gauzes,

21087.text:
that from their transparency are known in
the East as "woven air," and "running water,"

21093.text:
and "evening dew"; strange figured cloths
from Java; elaborate yellow Chinese hangings;

21100.text:
books bound in tawny satins or fair blue silks
and wrought with fleurs-de-lis, birds and

21107.text:
images; veils of lacis worked in Hungary point;
Sicilian brocades and stiff Spanish velvets;

21115.text:
Georgian work, with its gilt coins, and Japanese
Foukousas, with their green-toned golds and

vestments, as indeed he had for everything

21132.text:
connected with the service of the Church.
In the long cedar chests that lined the west

21138.text:
gallery of his house, he had stored away many
rare and beautiful specimens of what is really

21143.text:
the raiment of the Bride of Christ, who must
wear purple and jewels and fine linen that

21149.text:
she may hide the pallid macerated body that
is worn by the suffering that she seeks for

21155.text:
and wounded by self-inflicted pain. He possessed
a gorgeous cope of crimson silk and gold-thread

21163.text:
damask, figured with a repeating pattern of
golden pomegranates set in six-petalled formal

21168.text:
blossoms, beyond which on either side was
the pine-apple device wrought in seed-pearls.

21175.text:
The orphreys were divided into panels representing
scenes from the life of the Virgin, and the

21180.text:
coronation of the Virgin was figured in coloured
silks upon the hood. This was Italian work

21187.text:
of the fifteenth century. Another cope was
of green velvet, embroidered with heart-shaped

21193.text:
groups of acanthus-leaves, from which spread
long-stemmed white blossoms, the details of

21199.text:
which were picked out with silver thread and
coloured crystals. The morse bore a seraph's

21206.text:
head in gold-thread raised work. The orphreys
were woven in a diaper of red and gold silk,

21213.text:
and were starred with medallions of many saints
and martyrs, among whom was St. Sebastian.

21220.text:
He had chasubles, also, of amber-coloured
silk, and blue silk and gold brocade, and

21226.text:
yellow silk damask and cloth of gold, figured
with representations of the Passion and Crucifixion

21232.text:
of Christ, and embroidered with lions and
peacocks and other emblems; dalmatics of white

21239.text:
satin and pink silk damask, decorated with
tulips and dolphins and fleurs-de-lis; altar

21245.text:
frontals of crimson velvet and blue linen;
and many corporals, chalice-veils, and sudaria.

21253.text:
In the mystic offices to which such things
were put, there was something that quickened

21262.text:
For these treasures, and everything that he
collected in his lovely house, were to be

21267.text:
to him means of forgetfulness, modes by which
he could escape, for a season, from the fear

21274.text:
that seemed to him at times to be almost too
great to be borne. Upon the walls of the lonely

21281.text:
locked room where he had spent so much of
his boyhood, he had hung with his own hands

21287.text:
the terrible portrait whose changing features
showed him the real degradation of his life,

21293.text:
and in front of it had draped the purple-and-gold
pall as a curtain. For weeks he would not

21300.text:
go there, would forget the hideous painted
thing, and get back his light heart, his wonderful

21306.text:
joyousness, his passionate absorption in mere
existence. Then, suddenly, some night he would

21314.text:
creep out of the house, go down to dreadful
places near Blue Gate Fields, and stay there,

21320.text:
day after day, until he was driven away. On
his return he would sit in front of the picture,

21328.text:
sometimes loathing it and himself, but filled,
at other times, with that pride of individualism

21334.text:
that is half the fascination of sin, and smiling
with secret pleasure at the misshapen shadow

21341.text:
that had to bear the burden that should have
been his own.

21346.text:
After a few years he could not endure to be
long out of England, and gave up the villa

21351.text:
that he had shared at Trouville with Lord
Henry, as well as the little white walled-in

21356.text:
house at Algiers where they had more than
once spent the winter. He hated to be separated

21363.text:
from the picture that was such a part of his
life, and was also afraid that during his

21368.text:
absence some one might gain access to the
room, in spite of the elaborate bars that

21373.text: he had caused to be placed upon the door.

21377.text:
He was quite conscious that this would tell
them nothing. It was true that the portrait

21382.text:
still preserved, under all the foulness and
ugliness of the face, its marked likeness

21388.text:
to himself; but what could they learn from
that? He would laugh at any one who tried

21394.text:
to taunt him. He had not painted it. What
was it to him how vile and full of shame it

21400.text:
looked? Even if he told them, would they believe
it?

21404.text:
Yet he was afraid. Sometimes when he was down
at his great house in Nottinghamshire, entertaining

21411.text:
the fashionable young men of his own rank
who were his chief companions, and astounding

21416.text:
the county by the wanton luxury and gorgeous
splendour of his mode of life, he would suddenly

21422.text:
leave his guests and rush back to town to
see that the door had not been tampered with

21427.text:
and that the picture was still there. What
if it should be stolen? The mere thought made

21434.text:
him cold with horror. Surely the world would
know his secret then. Perhaps the world already

21443.text:
For, while he fascinated many, there were
not a few who distrusted him. He was very

21450.text:
nearly blackballed at a West End club of which
his birth and social position fully entitled

21455.text:
him to become a member, and it was said that
on one occasion, when he was brought by a

21460.text:
friend into the smoking-room of the Churchill,
the Duke of Berwick and another gentleman

21465.text:
got up in a marked manner and went out. Curious
stories became current about him after he

21472.text:
had passed his twenty-fifth year. It was rumoured
